fields.value: Replication data for: Democratization and International Border Agreements

dsDescriptionValue.value: Does the removal of salient external threats foster democratization? Recent research proposes an afﬁrmative answer but either fails to examine democratization at the monadic level, to consider small-scale democratization, or to account for factors known to inﬂuence the democratization process. The current study addresses this deﬁcit by (re)examining democratization during the period 1919–2006. The ﬁndings suggest a strong relationship between border settlement and democratization. A state that settles all of its interstate borders democratizes; any outstanding unsettled borders, however, prevent signiﬁcant democratization. Furthermore, although border settlement contributes to democratization, it does not signiﬁcantly affect democratic regime change. This empirical evidence cumulatively speciﬁes a more precise relationship between external threat and democratization than previous work and thereby contributes directly to the recent debate between the territorial and democratic peace theories. It also suggests that democratization may proceed more readily if states address unsettled borders ﬁrst.

publicationCitation.value: Owsiak, Andrew P. (2013) Democratization and International Border Agreements. Journal of Politics 75(3): 717-729.

value: Owsiak, Andrew P. (2012) Signing Up for Peace: International Boundary Agreements, Democracy, and Militarized Interstate Conflict. International Studies Quarterly 56(1):51-66.  Owsiak, Andrew P., and Toby J. Rider. (2013) Clearing the Hurdle: Border Settlement and Rivalry Termination. Journal of Politics 75(3): 757-772.
